criteria: Understanding of Body Systems and Subsystems
Use of Evidence to Support Arguments
Application of Systems and System Models Concept
descriptions: Demonstrates no understanding of the body as a system or its subsystems.
Shows a limited understanding of body systems, with difficulty identifying subsystems or their interactions.
Identifies some major body systems but struggles to explain how they interact or are composed of subsystems.
Explains how major body systems interact and are composed of subsystems (tissues, organs, cells), but with some inaccuracies or omissions.
Clearly explains how the body is a system of interacting subsystems composed of tissues, organs, and cells, providing accurate examples.
Provides a comprehensive and insightful explanation of the body as a complex system of interacting subsystems, including detailed examples and accurate terminology.
Provides no evidence or argument related to the body as a system.
Attempts to provide evidence but it is irrelevant or does not support the argument.
Provides some relevant evidence but struggles to connect it to the argument about body systems.
Supports arguments with relevant evidence, but the explanation of the connection between evidence and argument is not always clear.
Effectively uses evidence to support a clear and logical argument about how the body is a system of interacting subsystems.
Constructs a compelling and well-supported argument using a variety of evidence to demonstrate a deep understanding of the body as an interconnected system.
Does not demonstrate an understanding of systems or system models.
Shows limited awareness of systems concepts; unable to apply it to the human body.
Identifies the body as a system but does not explain how it relates to other systems or subsystems.
Describes the body as a system with subsystems but struggles to explain the interactions between them.
Demonstrates a good understanding of systems and system models by explaining how the body interacts with other systems and how its subsystems function together.

Demonstrates a sophisticated understanding of systems and system models, applying it to explain the complex interactions within the body and its relationship to larger systems, including potential impacts of external factors.
